content:
A compromise gets Rome off the hook for testing the euro zone’s debt rules

IN THE END, festive spirits prevailed—sort of. On December 19th the European Commission settled a quarrel with Italy’s populist government over its budget for 2019. The commission gave a grudging thumbs-up to a compromise plan which Giuseppe Conte (pictured), the Italian prime minister, had presented the night before to Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU’s commissioner for the euro.

Italy undertook to trim its nominal budget deficit from 2.4% of GDP to 2%. The commission reluctantly agreed that the structural deficit, which leaves out one-off measures and cyclical effects, should remain unchanged next year. “The solution on the table is not ideal,” Mr Dombrovskis grumbled. But ideal or not, it allows the commission to avoid opening a procedure that could have led to the imposition of multi-billion euro fines on Italy for straying from the path of fiscal righteousness (as mapped out by Brussels).

The row, which at times has been acrimonious and personal, demonstrated two things. The first is that the threat of EU sanctions works, especially on the stewards of an economy in trouble. Italy’s is yet again shrinking. In the third quarter, GDP fell by 0.1% compared with the previous quarter.

The Italian government’s hope was that pumping money into the economy could make it grow again. But if the commission had forced the Italian treasury to pay huge fines, it could have diminished, if not nullified, whatever impact the extra spending might have had. It was only when that reality sank in that Mr Conte’s deputies—Luigi Di Maio, the leader of the Five Star Movement (M5S), and Matteo Salvini, who heads the hard-right Northern League—began shuffling away from their previous intransigence.

The other lesson of the deal is that, for all the talk of EU bureaucracy, the European Commission is composed of politicians. Forced to choose, they put political requirements ahead of economic ones. They had just allowed France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, to get away with promising up to €10bn ($11bn) in extra spending to quell the rebellion of the gilets jaunes (yellow jackets), threatening to push France’s budget deficit next year well over the euro zone’s limit of 3% of GDP. That scarcely put them in a position to face down the Italians, whose projected deficit remains below 3% of GDP.

There may have been other considerations, too. In an interview with Corriere della Sera , a daily, Mr Conte said he had reminded the commission that his government “faced a duty to maintain social stability in Italy”.

Mr Conte emerged as one of the few winners from this rancorous affair. Hitherto regarded as a puppet of his deputies, the prime minister took over the negotiations from his finance minister, Giovanni Tria, and brokered a compromise. That will do much to enhance his standing.

If Mr Di Maio and Mr Salvini look more like losers, they have only themselves to blame. They brusquely ruled out any possible compromise, ensuring that the concessions, when they came, were seen as personal reverses. They compounded the impression of defeat by absenting themselves from Mr Conte’s announcement of the deal to parliament.

Arithmetically, at least, it was the European Commission that ceded the most. Its starting point had been an agreement with the previous government that the deficit would be held to 0.8% of GDP.

The real question, though, is whether Italy will win or lose. Mr Dombrovskis said next year’s budget did not offer solutions for the country’s long-term problems. He is right: it fails to tackle the crucial issue of Italy’s declining productivity. Then again, to meet Brussels’ demands, measures in the budget that might have given the economy a shot in the arm have been watered down. Infrastructure spending has been cut, and the introduction of an income support benefit for the hard-up has been put off until April 1st.

The government is expected to slash its prediction of GDP growth for 2019 to 1% from 1.5%. But even that looks optimistic. It may take more than festive spirits to keep Italy from lapsing into yet another recession next year.

Title: Italy and the European Commission reach a Christmas budget truce
